title: Describing People's Personality
summary: Adjectives for describing personality traits, including positive characteristics and negative/neutral qualities.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.content: In this lesson, you will learn how to describe different types of people using simple personality adjectives. We'll cover both positive traits and negative/neutral characteristics.

sections.heading: Positive Adjectives
sections.content: Words to describe favorable personality traits:

examples.example: Anna was friendly and welcomed me to the class.
The kind lady offered to drive me home.
The generous old man left the waiter a $20 tip.
Tom is so optimistic; he always sees the bright side of things.
Sue is a reliable person; she always keeps her promises.
Sam is very responsible, so I trust him with my children.
Harry is always cheerful, even when things go wrong.
Mary is so outgoing; she loves going to parties.
Joe is so easygoing. Nothing ever seems to bother him.
Tony is one of the most hardworking people I've met.

sections.heading: Negative or Neutral Adjectives
sections.content: Words to describe less favorable personality traits:

examples.example: Peter is so pessimistic; he makes me see the negative side.
Ken was unfriendly and didn't make me feel welcome.
The rude shop assistant took my money without speaking.
Little Henry cried when the mean boys took his ball.
Sally lost her job because she was unreliable.
I don't trust Tim alone at home. He's too irresponsible.
I wish Dan would smile more. He always looks miserable.
Jerry is a shy boy and rarely speaks in class.
Sara's lazy husband sits on the sofa all day.

sections.heading: Usage Tips
sections.content: Important notes about using personality adjectives:

examples.example: She is kind. / They are outgoing.
He seems shy at first, but he's actually very friendly.
After the accident, Tom became more pessimistic.
